Instrument_Host.name: Mars Exploration Rover 1
Instrument_Host.description:
The Mars Exploration Rover (MER) mission involved two identical spacecraft, Spirit (MER-2) and Opportunity (MER-1), sent to different landing sites on Mars. Data collection was facilitated by instruments on the rovers, which relayed information directly to NASA's Deep Space Network (DSN) or through Mars orbiters. The spacecraft's design drew from the Mars Pathfinder and included a complex entry, descent, and landing system utilizing a backshell, heat shield, lander, and parachute.
On Mars, the rovers, weighing 180 kg, were equipped with a sophisticated mobility system allowing them to traverse various terrains and were powered by solar panels and rechargeable batteries. They housed temperature-sensitive electronics to withstand harsh Martian conditions, and their communication systems allowed for data transmission to Earth and between Mars orbiters.
The Athena Science Payload on each rover enabled advanced analysis of Martian soil and rocks, with instruments mounted on a robotic arm and a panoramic camera for imaging. The rovers utilized various cameras for navigation and hazard detection. The DSN, managed by NASAâ€™s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, facilitated two-way communication with the spacecraft using high-power antennas located globally. In addition, the 2001 Mars Odyssey orbiter supported data relay from the rovers while also conducting its scientific missions.
